indicator.title: Output Indicator
indicator.description: • Regulatory and enforcement capacity in place • Obsolete pesticides disposed of • PCBs phased out and disposed of • Reduced risk of exposure to POPs of project-affected people • Knowledge management packages developed, and • Viability/cost-effectiveness of alternatives to POPs, particularly in Theme-1, is demonstrated in a number of settings

baseline.comment:
Stockholm Convention is not fully incorporated into national legislation. The POPs National Implementation identifies following priorities:
• Disposal of obsolete POPs chemicals and decontamination of POPs-infested areas • Development of alternative strategies for malaria vector management with reduced—or no—reliance on DDT

target.comment: Completion of Responsible Care programme Disposal of additional Hazardous waste Theme 2: completion of IVM documentary Completion of Integrated Vector Management volunteer work.

actual.comment:
Theme 1 co-financing has been obtained from the public and the sector in order to dispose of additional hazardous waste to the tune of USD 45 K. As at end June 2014, the UN approved packaging had reached Mauritius and packaging was about to start.
(a) A capacity building and awareness raising workshop held in February 2014 by International Consultant (Polyeco SA) responsible for the disposal of POPs chemicals and DDT contaminated soil on handling, packaging and transport of POPs for disposal. (50 participants from Public, private and NGO directly involved in the handling of hazardous waste have been trained)
(b)On 25 April 2014 a National Consultant (Dr Choong from University of Mauritius) has been recruited to the tune of Rs 390,000 for the delivery of training under the RCP.
(c) Four pamphlets including artwork targeting Households, Workplaces (industries), Laboratories and Agricultural sector have been prepared and will be finalised in July 2014 .
(d) 8 training workshops are scheduled in September 2014, targeting participants from both public and private sector organisations including laboratories, agricultural sector, chemical Industries and health sector.
a) Equipment procured by MOHQL as at 2014 in the POPs Project to the tune of Rs 828 432 ($27614.4 x Rs.30/= $1)-.. b) Evaluation of alternative insecticides to DDT are ongoing: Insecticide susceptibility tests were carried out using Deltamethrin and cypermethrin by wall bioassays; mosquito repellency tests using prallethrin mats and liquid diffusers; and larval assays using Temephos and Dimillin (larval growth regulators)
The Ministry of Health and Quality of Life has designated a medical doctor responsible for the subject of public Health as IVM Coordinator. The IVM Coordinator being office based, it was decided to have an IVM coordinator assistant to work on the field and moblise the volunteers. The TOR for the IVM Coordinator Assistant has been developed and the advertisement floated by UND

target.comment: Completion of Terminal Evaluation Completion of Responsible Care programme COmpletion of IVM volunteer work. Disposal of Ethylene Oxide Cylinders

actual.comment: The Terminal EValuation was completed in June 2015 The responsible care programme was completed following the national awareness campaign in September 2015 The IVM volunteer work was completed in March, with the final report of the IVM coordinator assistant Co-financing has been identified for the disposal of ethylene oxide cylinders.

result.title: Objective
result.description: Objective: To expand, and ensure effective management of, the protected area network to safeguard threatened biodiversity

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: 1. Coverage (ha) of the terrestrial formal protected area network of mainland Mauritius and the islets:

baseline.comment:
State protected areas
8,027ha
Private protected areas
0ha

target.comment:
State protected areas
11,700ha
Private protected areas
3,220ha

actual.comment:
The status quo in terms of protected areas has been maintained.
State Protected areas = 8,328 ha
Private protected areas = 0 ha
For Bassin Blanc, acquisition under appeal in valuation tribunal is still not finalized.
The management plans for the Bras d'Eau National Park and Black River Gorges National Park have been submitted during this reporting period.Both document proposes the creation of buffer zones , these will be delineated in the mapping under the Protected Area Network Expansion Strategy. Yet, the whole process of declaring the land around the parks must be initiated by the Ministry of Housing and Lands which is the local authority to define the land uses.
Regarding Mountain and River Reserves which covers approximately 6500 ha of privately managed land , their status as protected areas is still unclear. The Protected Area Network Expansion Strategy , expected for September 2015, will provide the underpinnings for adding these reserves and other potential reserves such as the corridor of 4000 metres linking Le Morne to the Black River Gorges National Park, to the protected area networks.
Concerning the Native Terrestrial Biodiversity and National Parks Bill, which makes provision for proclamation of of private reserves, is expected to be presented to the parliament in October 2015.

indicator.title: Indicator 2
indicator.description:
2. Total operational budget (including HR and capital budget) allocation (US$) for protected area management
[Note added to clarify that this indicator refers to the annual budget]

target.comment: More than US$4.1m

actual.comment: Target can be considered as being achieved. The total budget for PA's as Government budget allocation 2014 is estimated to be $ 6.2 m for the Forestry services and $ 2.4 m ( include funds from PAN project, approximately $800,000) for the National Parks and Conservation services. Additional funds of ~ US $0.25 m from National Parks and conservation funds has been used for Protected Areas. Other financing mechanism are also now in place such a Maurice Ile Durable (MID) fund to the tune of~ US $ 0 .4 m, for Protected Areas management. Moreover funds from private companies Corporate Social Responsibility ( CSR) have also been allocated as follows: HSBC= US $ 25,000 IBL= US $ 2,500 , Lions clubs = US $ 8,500. Total budget amounts to US $9.25 m

indicator.title: Indicator 3
indicator.description: 3. Financial sustainability score (%) for national systems of protected areas

baseline.comment: Baseline application of the of the Financial Sustainability Scorecard (2009) yielded a general score of 17%

target.comment:
Application of the of the Financial Sustainability Scorecard at project end is expected to yield a general score 30-40%
[Target adjusted after conclusion of inception report]

actual.comment: Target achieved. Financial Scorecard has not been re-worked for this reporting period Initiatives undertaken in 2013 and 2014 to improve the financial score of the PAs are still ongoing . Private companies are still directly contributing to PAs management in terms of ecosystem restoration and IAS removal activities in the PAs. The lions club , a service group, is channeling CSR funds from private companies for IAS clearing and forest restoration activities. The Maurice Ile Durable has continued to fund PA management and Ecosystem restoration in newly identified areas. There will soon be another source of funds from the European Union. The Indian Ocean Commission (IOC) have called for proposal for local biodiversity project to the tune of US $ 36 000 to US $ 90 000 per project.Deadline for submission of Project is August 2015.

indicator.title: Indicator 4
indicator.description: 4. Capacity development indicator score (%) for protected area system:

baseline.comment:
Systemic 50%
Institutional 56%
Individual 62%

target.comment:
Systemic 78%
Institutional 60%
Individual 75%
[Target adjusted after conclusion of inception report]

actual.comment:
The Scorecard has not been applied again. Hence, it is not possible to inform the indicator. The Capacity development indicator will be calculated after the training programme has been finalized. The score generated will serve as a baseline. The Capacity Development indicator will be generated a second time after training completed and the outcome will be measure against the baseline.
Concerning the training need analysis, the exercise is nearly completed and data analysis should start soon.
Otherwise , an ecological restoration workshop to share good eco-system restoration practice through the development of a practitioners' guide/manual , is planned for September/October 2015.
Regarding actual training carried out during this reporting period, there has been two training sessions in December 2014 on the use of GPS. Staff from the Forestry services , NPCS and Ministry of Housing and Lands attended the training.

indicator.title: Indicator 4
indicator.description:
9. Reach of the communications and awareness programme as follows:
9a) Percentage of those participating in experiential learning programmes instigated by the PAN who show enhanced knowledge
9b) Percentage of those participating in experiential learning programmes instigated by the PAN who show positive changes in behavior.
[NOTE ON LOGFRAME REVISION 2014:]
Indicator #9 has been revised as a result of the MTR. It was not being properly informed in previous reporting periods anyway.
It was previously formulated as follows:
â€œReach (estimated number of people) of the communications and awareness programmeâ€
The MTR recommended this changed. The response was:
Reach indicator does not tell us anything about the take-up of messages. This indicator will be improved. It will be based upon surveys of target audiences and these groups will be surveyed for changes in their knowledge, attitudes and practices regarding general issues of biodiversity conservation in Mauritius and specific project protected area network objectives.
Training indicators have been revised to be outcome-oriented.

baseline.comment:
In order to adequately assess the target, now as a % of those reached out by the project, tailored surveys will need to be applied.
[NOTE ON LOGFRAME REVISION 2014:]
The baseline for indicator #9 It was previously formulated as follows:
â€œBroad-based communications (estimated number of audience receiving different media message) t.b.d.
Outreach programmes (number of people attending) t.b.d.
Experiential learning programmes (number of people attending) t.b.d.
Lobbying of key decision-makers (number of people and institutions) t.b.d.â€

target.comment:
9a) : At least 80% of those participating in experiential learning programmes show enhanced knowledge and attitude
9b) At least 50% of those participating in experiential learning programmes show positive changes in behavior.
[NOTE ON LOGFRAME REVISION 2014:]
Target for indicator #9 It was previously formulated as follows:
â€œBroad-based communications (estimated number of audience receiving different media message) approx. 100,000.
Outreach programmes (number of people attending) approx. 500.
Experiential learning programmes (number of people attending) approx. 500.
Lobbying of key decision-makers (number of people and institutions) 10 of 4.â€

actual.comment:
Further progress have been made towards the target. Since the facebook page has been created in July 2014 , the number of likes has add up to 960 . The awareness campaign is still being implemented with future experiential events coming. A National art competition on the theme of world biodiversity was launched on the 8th May 2015 and all entries had to be submitted on the 18th May 2015. The PMU is going to do a thorough analysis of the exercise and its output to create a baseline.Results from future competition will be compared to the baseline to find out whether there has been changes.
In addition, a national survey will be undertaken at the close of the awareness programme to look at changes in knowledge and behaviour.

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: 10. Number of strategic plans prepared for PA institutions that are linked to the MTEF

target.comment:
3
[Target adjusted after conclusion of inception report]

actual.comment:
There has been tangible progress towards this target.The review of the Bras d'Eau National Park Management plan has been fully reviewed and will soon go for public consultation process. Review of the Bras D'Eau operational plan has been completed in June 2015 and comments have been communicated to the International Team of Consultants for amendments.
Regarding the Black River Gorges National Park9BRGNP) Management plan, a first draft was submitted on the 16th February 2015. An amended version together with the annual operation plan (AOP) was submitted in June 2015 after comments were communicated. The PMU is actually driving the review of the BRGNP AOP.
Concerning the strategic planning, there has been continuous consultation with FS and NPCS during the different EcoAfrica missions .The submission of the strategic planning should follow the PANES.

actual.comment:
Target not yet achieved. The international team of consultants has submitted a first discussion paper on Conservation stewardship in April 2015 for review and comments.
The Ministry has approved the 7 Memorandun of Understanding between the private forest owners for IAS clearing and forest restoration on private lands in September 2014, The first installment was paid in January 2015. The National steering committee on the 28th May 2015 has approved to the request to increase the number of MOUs as IAS clearing is more cost effective under this scheme.

actual.comment:
For this reporting period, there has not been much improvement with respect to 2013 reporting.
14a) Short Training Course: There has been two training sessions on the use of GPS . 15 staff members from the forestry service, National Park and Conservation Services and Ministry of Housing and lands were trained.
14b) Approaching and reaching 3, when target is 5 Mentoring programme:29 Parks Rangers ,Assistant Park Rangers, Forest Enforcement and Conservation Officer
14c) Approaching and reaching 3, when target is 5 Train-the-trainers programme :16 Park Rangers and Assistant Park Rangers .
14d) IAS and ecosystem restoration skills development, 43 manual workers, 4 Park Rangers 12 Assistant Parks Rangers, 10 Forest Officers are regularly trained on IAS removal and native forest restoration.

result.title: Outcome 3
result.description: Outcome 3. Operational know-how in place to contain threats

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: 15. Number of protected areas with updated and approved management plans

target.comment: 3 or more

actual.comment: Approaching the target. Much progress has been achieved with the submission of Draft management plans for the Bras d'Eau National parks in 2014 and the Black River Gorges National Parks in February 2015. The Former will soon go for a 2 months public review while the amended BRGNP management plan has just been submitted. For RTREBS , the drafting of the management plan should be completed by the end of 2015.

indicator.title: Indicator 2
indicator.description: 16. Extent of area (ha) under active IAS management and ecosystem restoration

baseline.comment: 60 ha

target.comment:
500 ha
[Target adjusted after conclusion of inception report]

actual.comment: Progress: More than 70% of target achieved. The area under conservation management area with active IAS management and ecosystem restoration achieved during this reporting period has increased to 369.18 ha -- that is 73.8 % of the target has been achieved. Maintenance weeding has already been carried out in 67.25 ha of native forests.A total of 21105 seedlings have been planted to June 2015.

actual.comment: Target has been achieved for initial weeding (17a) and is still progressing on follow up maintenance with a cost currently at 850 USD per ha (17b).The cost cannot be further decreased due to inflation and higher cost of living.

target.comment:
Second Steering committee, held.
Cape Verde A multi-sectoral participatory IWRM planning workshop held Logframe updated and a draft monitoring plan; Communication plan elaborated Draft report on studies on wastewater improvement available.
Comoros: PMU in place and equipping office completed; Draft TOR for the water resource assessment and watershed management elaborated; Log frame updated through participatory approach; Interim water committee established, awareness campaign on solid waste management and river cleaning. Study on household solid waste generation.
Maldives: Recruitment of project manager; Participatory IWRM planning workshop held. The multi-sectoral stakeholders workshop held.
Mauritius: Recruitment of Project Manager; Participatory Planning Workshop held
Sao Tome: Participatory IWRM planning workshop for the demonstration project held.
Seychelles: First formal stakeholders meeting held. Monitoring and Evaluation Plan finalized, Communication and awareness raising strategy discussed and feedbacks taken into account for the final version; Water Conservation Awareness Campaign held
Project Management : The project management unit consisting of a Project Director and a Project Manager effectively help the participating countries to deliver on the project.

actual.comment:
From the Second Steering committee, it was observed that in ll the SIDS, National partners have knowledge of IWRM concepts and their roles in implementing IWRM. However, they do not have all the tools to implement IWRM. Project demonstrations in the SIDS are all ongoing, at different stages of progress. In at least two SIDS they are in implementation. The least advanced are Mauritius, Maldives and Sao Tome. In Cape Verde, Mauritius and Seychelles, there is already a monitoring framework for water quality management.
Cape Verde A multi-sectoral participatory IWRM planning workshop was held in February 2014 bringing together stakeholders (Tarrafal Municipality, agriculture, environment, NGOs, farmer representatives). Logframe updated and a draft monitoring plan; Communication plan has been elaborated through consultancy; Draft report on studies on wastewater improvement available.
Comoros: PMU is in place with 3 staff in Anjouan comprising Project Manager, Technical Assistant and Administrative Assistant. Rehabilitation and equipping office was completed; The draft TOR for the water resource assessment and watershed management has elaborated but there has been proposed changes approach; Log frame has been updated through participatory approach; Interim water committee was established in January 2014 and three meetings held; Major awareness campaign on solid waste management and river cleaning was jointly organised with the Municipality authority and other stakeholders in the framework of the interim coordination committee. Study on household solid waste generation is underway in collaboration with University of Le Maine in France. Three graduate students from the University are working closely with the Regional Directorate of Environment and the PMU.
Maldives: After three advertisements, the project did not get a qualified candidate; Participatory IWRM planning workshop was held in March to initiate participatory planning and implementat

target.comment:
IWRM demonstration projects ongoing in all six countries with functional IWRM coordination committees at Basin level.
Cape Verde: Technical design completed and recommendations available Selection of household connection completed and 500 households mapped for connection to main sewer-line. Halophite plants planted to mitigate seashore erosion and salinization Targeted awareness campaigns held. Participatory IWRM workshop held.
Comoros: Water resource assessment initiated and draft reports available. Socioeconomic assessment and participatory mapping and zoning initiated and draft reports available. A watershed management plan completed . Consultation on solid waste management ongoing, scenarios for solid waste management discussed. Establishment of a tripartite partnership with the University of Comoros, the Directorate of Water and Energy and Directorate of Environment and Forest w In March and April 2015, Training for small scale farmers held to promote soil erosion control practices. Workshops held on the development of watershed management plans for Mutsamundu river basin, and implementation approach agreed on
An integrated water supply plan was completed and technical design prepared and approved. 100% (about 2000) population of the Island will have have portable water supply. Bidding was completed and contractor hired. Works was commissioned by the Minister in May 2015 Water planning Committee for the Island was established, and actively involved in planning. The committee involves the Island Authorities, technical departments such as agriculture and fisheries as well as education and community representatives.
Mauritius: As regards Output 1.4.1: Water Resources Assessment conducted to determine and monitor the safe yield and water quality of the aquifer - a consultant was appointed and specifications prepared for the drilling of 4-5 boreholes and installation of piezometers. Output 1.4.2: Improved water quality protection of the gro

actual.comment:
IWRM demonstration projects are ongoing in all six countries with functional IWRM coordination committees at Basin level. Through the multi-stakeholder plat forms and participatory approach, the project has created platform for addressing water challenges and awareness raising, effectively raising awareness at national level on benefits of IWRM adoption. Following the demonstration project intervention, number of gaps have been identified and policy recommendations made.
Cape Verde: Technical design completed and recommendations available Selection of household connection has been completed and 580 household mapped for connection to main sewer-line. This is expected to increase volume of wastewater by 40% A total of 1750 halophite plants were planted to mitigate seashore erosion and salinization Seven major targeted awareness campaigns have been held reaching out to over 750 people. This include two events during a national fair on Environment in 2014 and 2015 in which over 250 persons visited the project promotional stand. In February 2014, a 3-days participatory IWRM workshop was held, raising awareness among key national level senior officials (a total of 28 participants representing different departments in the water sector). From September to November 2014, awareness raising events on theme "water is life" were held in Tarraffal involving primary and secondary schools students and teachers. Over 200 students were involved and sensitized.
Comoros: Water resource assessment initiated and draft reports available. Socioeconomic assessment and participatory mapping and zoning initiated and draft reports available. A watershed management plan is expected to be completed by September 2015. Consultation on solid waste management is ongoing, scenarios for solid waste management have discussed. A monthly solid waste cleaning day has been agreed on. Additionally, through project mobilization, several solid waste collection campaigns were held involving the gene

Through the multi-stakeholder plat forms and participatory approach, the project has created platform for addressing water challenges and awareness raising, effectively raising awareness at national level on benefits of IWRM adoption. Following the demonstration project intervention, number of gaps have been identified and policy recommendations made.

result.title: Outcome 1.1 (Cape Verde)
result.description:
Protection of groundwater resources, stabilization of coastal terrains and promotion of productive activities at coastal areas through the integrated planning and management of wastewater collection, treatment and reuse demonstrated in Tarrafal in the Island of Santiago Outputs:
1.1.1: Improved wastewater management systems, resulting in more treated wastewater as a alternative water source and reduced untreated wastewater discharge to the ground
1.1.2: Increased treated wastewater used for irrigation, resulting in less groundwater abstraction and increased crop productivity by the communities
1.1.3: Awareness raised on water use efficiency for domestic use as well as tourism sector

actual.comment:
Technical design completed and recommendations available
Selection of household connection has been completed and 580 household mapped for connection to main sewer-line. This is expected to increase volume of wastewater by 40%
A total of 1750 halophite plants were planted to mitigate seashore erosion and salinization
Seven major targeted awareness campaigns have been held reaching out to over 750 people. This include two events during a national fair on Environment in 2014 and 2015 in which over 250 persons visited the project promotional stand. In February 2014, a 3-days participatory IWRM workshop was held, raising awareness among key national level senior officials (a total of 28 participants representing different departments in the water sector). From September to November 2014, awareness raising events on theme "water is life" were held in Tarraffal involving primary and secondary schools students and teachers. Over 200 students were involved and sensitized.

result.title: Outcome 1.2 (Comoros)
result.description:
Improved water source protection through IWRM Planning and management in Mutsamudu on the island of Anjouan
Outputs:
1.2.1: Water resource assessment and monitoring systems established
1.2.2: Water quality improved through solid waste management and water source protection
1.2.3: Reservoir protected from the effects of small-scale farming practices
1.2.4: Watershed management plan for Mutsamudu developed
1.2.5: Awareness raised on IWRM and catchment management and its contribution to MDGs and gender empowerment

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description:
Water resources assessed at identified monitoring points; Water resource monitoring operational
Solid waste collection system established and operational
Volume/weight solid waste collected
Volume/area of monitoring point covered in solid waste
Catchment management committee established
Watershed management plan
# of training and awareness raising campaigns, with gender dis-aggregated data, on water source protection from solid waste and agricultural practice

baseline.comment:
No water quality or quantity monitoring data collected
No collection system; amount of solid waste in River Mutsamudu not monitored
No committee exists
No plan exists; no data collection or analysis exists to provide basis for management plan
No community engagement on solid waste pollution; little awareness observed

target.comment:
Regular water resources monitoring programme established
# of households increased serviced by solid waste collection system
30% reduction in solid waste observed at the monitoring point upstream of water supply intake;
Committee established with clear TORs and operational
Consultation with landowners and catchment s/h completed; watershed surveys conducted; watershed zone map produced; management plan endorsed by stakeholders
Clean up campaigns attended by communities; all farmers in the area around reservoirs trained in best farming practice to reduce pollution on reservoir

actual.comment:
Water resource assessment initiated and draft reports available. Socioeconomic assessment and participatory mapping and zoning initiated and draft reports available. A watershed management plan is expected to be completed by September 2015.
Consultation on solid waste management is ongoing, scenarios for solid waste management have discussed. A monthly solid waste cleaning day has been agreed on. Additionally, through project mobilization, several solid waste collection campaigns were held involving the general public, schools and military. Over 50% of the population of Anjuaon has been sensitized through various channels including outreach activities, workshops, and media (local radio and press).
in April 2015, a tripartite partnership with the University of Comoros, the Directorate of Water and Energy and Directorate of Environment and Forest was established for water quality monitoring. Under the partnership, the laboratory of the University of Comoros has been upgraded for water quality monitoring. On the other-hand, the University is providing ongoing technical support in monitoring and training.
In March and April 2015, two training for small scales farmers was held to promote soil erosion control practices. Training included onsite demonstration of good practices in which 10 small scale farmers were involved.
Two workshops were held on the development of watershed management plans for Mutsamundu river basin, and implementation approach agreed on.

result.title: Outcome 1.3 (Maldives)
result.description:
Protection of the freshwater lens of Thoddoo Island from salinization and agro-chemical pollution, with improved drought season aquifer yields
Outputs:
1.3.1: Sustainable and innovative groundwater extraction system (infiltration gallery system) established and operational
1.3.2: Agricultural practices improved, reducing groundwater contamination
1.3.3: Sustainable groundwater extraction systems accepted nationally as relevant to island potable water supply and planned for replication nationally.
1.3.4: Groundwater quality monitoring system established and operational by gender balanced trained locals

Reduced groundwater salinity(%) and electrical conductivity
Reduced nitrates and phosphates in GW

Limited baseline water quality data
No water provided from the system, All groundwater extracted from individual wells, no metering.
Currently elevated salinity and electrical conductivity

Non existent

target.comment:
50% wells on faming plots and 50% of household wells monitored
50% of agricultural plots on the island irrigated from the gallery System
Salinity level below 700 µS/cm, 30% reduction from average baseline salinity level
30% reduction from the baseline data
Gender balanced training given to farmers; 20 shallow boreholes established for GW quality monitoring

actual.comment:
An integrated water supply plan was completed and technical design prepared and approved. 100% (about 2000) population of the Island will have have portable water supply.
Bidding was completed and contractor hired. Works was commissioned by the Minister in May 2015
Water planning Committee for the Island was established, and actively involved in planning. The committee involves the Island Authorities, technical departments such as agriculture and fisheries as well as education and community representatives.

result.title: Outcome 1.4 (Mauritius)
result.description:
The protection and sustainable utilization of the Northern Aquifer of Mauritius demonstrated through the integrated planning and management of wastewater collection, treatment and reuse
Outputs
1.4.1: Water Resources Assessment conducted to determine and monitor the safe yield and water quality of the aquifer
1.4.2: Improved water quality protection of the groundwater and lagoon water quality through improved wastewater treatment and management systems
1.4.3. Reduced stress on the aquifer through improved water demand management and dissemination of best practices, aiming for replication at the national level and beyond
1.4.4. Capacity strengthened and awareness raised among government, private sector and civil society for aquifer protection against over-extraction and contamination with special focus on climate change and gender empowerment

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description:
Water Quality Baseline developed: Vulnerability of the aquifer against pollution and extraction assessed
Increased m3 of treated wastewater reused as alternative water resources (for recharge, irrigation, etc.)
(co-fin)
Impact assessment of the effectiveness of groundwater recharge using the treated wastewater against saline intrusion.
Best practices for water demand management captured and disseminated to % of stakeholder bodies;
# of briefings produced by % of stakeholders on water resource management and climate change/gender empowerment

baseline.comment:
Limited hydrogeological data on the northern Aquifer
1500m3 per day injected in boreholes
Effectiveness of the current practice unknown
Limited awareness of policy makers about the importance to protect groundwater and lagoon;
Limited awareness about saving water and polluting activities

actual.comment:
As regards Output 1.4.1: Water Resources Assessment conducted to determine and monitor the safe yield and water quality of the aquifer - a consultant was appointed and specifications prepared for the drilling of 4-5 boreholes and installation of piezometers.
Output 1.4.2: Improved water quality protection of the groundwater and lagoon water quality through improved wastewater treatment and management systems - The Wastewater Treatment Plant at Grand Baie has been operating and at the same time the consultancy services for the detail design for house connections has been awarded. It is expected that the house connections will be started in 2016.
1.4.3. Reduced stress on the aquifer through improved water demand management and dissemination of best practices, aiming for replication at the national level and beyond - A school competition was launched in May 2015 to raise awareness on water management and enhance the understanding of IWRM in the population.
1.4.4. Capacity strengthened and awareness raised among government, private sector and civil society for aquifer protection against over-extraction and contamination with special focus on climate change and gender empowerment - This will take place after the results from the drilling and water samples are analyzed.

result.title: Outcome 1.5 (Sao Tome & Principe)
result.description:
Integrated River basin management plan for the Rio Provaz Basin developed to enable equitable water resources allocation and protection, contributing to sustainable economic development, public health and environmental protection.
Outputs:
1.5.1: Quality and quantity of water Resources in the Rio Provaz basin assessed
1.5.2: Institutional capacity (cross-sectoral coordination) strengthened and decentralized (municipal) water management fostered through the development and implementation of Basin Water Resources Allocation and Protection Strategy
1.5.3: Water pollution reduced through improved wastewater treatment systems (piloting ECOSAN wastewater management), solid waste collection and disposal and residential sanitation at the poor communities.
1.5.4: Awareness raised of IWRM at the basin level to strengthen community participation in IWRM and to ensure sustainability

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description:
Area surveyed and reported
Water resources level, flow and quality data; GW resources potential established
Basin water management committee; Basin Water Resources Allocation and Protection Strategy
# of households using Ecosan

baseline.comment:
No formal inventories of land or water resources or use exists
No regular data collection or quality assurance
No stakeholder consultations on water resources management to date; no catchment management committee: no water resources management strategies at basin level or national level
No Ecosan technology currently used

target.comment:
100% of catchments area surveyed
Robust quantity and quality data sets collected; all major risk type assessed for GW extraction
Stakeholders identified; Gender integrated catchment management committees established and operational; water resources management strategy developed in a participatory manner and endorsed by the basin stakeholders; the process at the demo basin informs the national level IWRM process
100% of constructed Ecosan units still in use at the end of the project (# of units TBD during the inception phase); lessons learned produced aiming for further promotion

actual.comment:
Water Resource Assessment and mapping of Rio Provaz Basin was undertaken. 100% of the basin has been surveyed and mapped and draft reported submitted. Water resource status has been simulated from limited data available.
Basin coordination committee established; at list 5 meeting held; committee members are trained on 7 relevant aspects.
On solid waste, a large amount of solid waste has been cleared, and this continues with an estimated solid waste collection at 20 m3 per month. Several awareness campaigns have been carried out to raise awareness on river basin protection, at least 50% of the population has been reached.
A specialized firm to support on Eco-sanitation promotion, training and construction has been recruited. Work is scheduled to start thereafter.

result.title: Outcome 1.6 (Seychelles)
result.description:
Protection of a coastal gravel aquifer through integrated land and water management measures (water demand management, land use, flood management) demonstrated in the island of La Digue
Outputs:
1.6.1: Water abstraction reduced through water demand management measures, including rainwater harvesting, household water tanks to reduce peak water demand, wastewater reuse, improved metering and tariff reform
1.6.2: Groundwater availability and quality improved through improved septic tank management, wastewater collection and treatment, prevention of seawater intrusion, solid waste collection, and groundwater recharge.

m3 of re-used effluent

% reduction in leakage in water supply distribution system
Surface water salinity in marsh outlets and GW salinity; aquifer recharge capacity of marshland restored
Volume of waste oils and batteries collected

baseline.comment:
Rainwater harvesting practiced only marginally
No wastewater reuse practiced
Limited # of households with potable water storage tanks
No leakage detection and reduction programme; bulk metering only at water treatment plant;
Inflow of seawater at high tide conditions; no tidal flaps installed; development pressure reduced natural buffering capacity of marshland
Existing collection programmes not effective no collection

target.comment:
100% of targeted buildings using rainwater at domestic and commercial levels
Landscape irrigation schemes using treated wastewater at two hotels
Mandatory installation of potable water storage tanks for all new buildings
10% reduction in system peak pressures
District meters installed and monitored;
# of leaks fixed; #m of damaged pipes replaced #% reduction of m3 of water loss (#s TBD during the inception)
4 tidal flaps installed; no seawater flows inland into marshes; reinstatement of the marshland
70% of households using collection system

actual.comment:
Rainwater harvesting promoted, 55 house holds adopted rainwater harvesting (with storage tanks at subsidized rates).
Consultancy on technical design and cost-benefit analysis of waste water treatment was undertaken. Hotels were involved and sensitized on the benefits of adoption of the water treatment.
Study on the solid waste disposal was completed and part of the recommendations on improvements taken up during the reporting period. Through collaboration with the Landscape and Solid Waste Management authority, a task was completed on collection of all batteries in the Island. Project also supported the regular solid waste collection through provision of more bins for solid waste collection.
Several awareness campaigns were held during major national and international water and environment events involving the general public and schools

result.title: Outcome 5.1
result.description:
Project implemented effectively and efficiently to the satisfaction of partners
Outputs:
5.1.1 Capable human resources and efficient systems support project implementation
5.1.2 Monitoring, consultation and advisory mechanisms support project implementation

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: Project systems work efficiently to provide high quality technical support to countries in IWRM reforms and demonstrations

baseline.comment: No project,

target.comment: Effectively and efficiently implemented project

actual.comment:
The Results and Knowledge Management Specialist (as part of the Regional Coordination Unit) undertook monitoring and support visit to all the countries during the reporting period. During the visit, project progress and challenges were discussed and recommendation made. The Regional Coordination Unit organized a Regional Workshop for all the National Focal Points and the Demonstration Project Manager. The UNDP RTA and UNEP Task Manager participated in the workshop. The workshop provided unique opportunity for networking, monitoring on progress as well as
backstopping.
In addition to the regular backstopping by the RTA, the visit to Seychelles Demonstration project was undertaken in June 2015 by the UNDP RTA.

actual.comment: Under Lot 1, Econoler has carried out a one-day inception workshop on 07 July 2015. It was a platform for the Consultants to introduce the participants to the project and their firm. They provided their appreciation regarding the SIDS-Dock project’s framework and indicators and discussed on the methodology for the study. The Consultants further elaborated on the approach they would adopt concerning the customization of the MBEAT/Excel software. The Consultants also explained on their approach to conducting Energy Audits and to ensuring compatibility of the Energy Audit Management Scheme (EAMS) adopted by EEMO with the outcomes of the study. The participants also had the opportunity to provide their comments and suggestions regarding the various aspects of the inception report. Under Lot 2, Econoler has already carried out 3 missions to Mauritius. During the first mission, a one-day inception workshop was held on 16 June 2015. It was a platform for the Consultants to introduce the participants to the project and their firm. They provided their appreciation regarding the SIDS-Dock project’s framework and indicators and discussed on the methodology for the study. The Consultants also elaborated on the approach they would adopt concerning the review of the existing GoM architectural specifications and construction methods. The Consultants further explained on their approach to developing the MS Excel-based software tool and to developing the Energy Efficiency Building Code Compliance Scheme (EEBCCS). The participants also had the opportunity to provide their comments and suggestions regarding the various aspects of the inception report. During the second mission, a one-day consultative workshop was held on 29 July 2015. It was a platform where the Consultants introduced the participants on the Energy Efficiency Building Regulations (EEBR) and the Energy Efficiency Building Code (EEBC) project backgrounds and statuses. They presented the elements of the EEBR and EEBC

indicator.title: Output Indicator
indicator.description:
Increased inclusion of the poor in ministerial (MSIEE) pro-poor programmes.
Quality of M & E Framework of the NEF projects by NEF staff.
The NSA’s capacity to design and utilise M&E tools at project level.
The presence of a Gender Specific Professional.
The number of local federations of social actors; the number of self-managed federations of social actors. The number of federations that are capable of identifying community development or pro-poor priorities.

baseline.comment:
Absence of a coordinated participatory community development approach to ensure optimal coverage for the poor in Mauritius/Rodrigues.
The current ministerial (MSIEE) database of beneficiaries amongst the poor used for the provision of services is unreliable: rough estimates suggest that both leakage and under-coverage are significant (about 35%).
There is an absence of any formal M & E framework for projects, formulated and implemented by the National Empowerment Foundation (NEF). The NEF does not have the ability to translate results into information requirements on an ongoing basis.
The specific needsof excluded groups, especially women are not yet adequately addressed through Community Development.
Mauritius/Rodrigues does not have locally and participatory integrated community development.

target.comment:

Output 2:
GBV in Rodrigues Gender policies for Ministry of Gender and Equality
Output 3: -UN agencies program implementation -Community Development Research -Policy Development Support & Civil Society Research -Partnership and Networks -Support of Volunteerism -Professionalisation of Social Sector -Media Promotion -South- South Collaborationn

Output 3: For pilot area - Black River:
Structuration of existing platforms at Black River Establishment of programme governance structure/community participation with 30 Local organizations/NGOs/ CSRs - Legally registered Undertake baseline surveys in collaboration with UNhabitat Visibility: presence in the press through newsletters, interviews, word of mouth, support to partners’ initiative; use of partners’ premises to get the message across valorization, promotion and development of volunteerism to consolidate the platform Media campaign – web-site and a film on the Kolektif Rivier Nwar 5 A 5 year Strategic Plan has been developed and approved by the Rivier Nwar Platform Providing basic sanitation facilities to poor families (partnerships with private sector, engineer analysis and reports, specs, execution). . Social Leadership skills training offered
For Pilot area: Le Morne Prepare Denetralized Cooperation Programme project on toilets
For Pilot area- Rodrigues 1.Gender Based Violence (GBV) The Gender Based Violence campaign was launched successfully on the 28th of January

actual.comment: Output1: In line with paragraphs 173-179 of the March 2015 government Budget Speech 2015-2016, and the cabinet decision on 3rd April 2015, regarding the Marshall plan against poverty, the government of Mauritius has adopted to use the Social Register Mauritius (SRM) for the NEF School Materials scheme and other social protection programmes .From June-December 2015, in partnership with the Ministry of Social Security (MSS), Ministry of Finance and Economic Development (MoFED), the Nation Empowerment Foundation (NEF) and with the assistance of Statistics Mauritius(SM) and the United Nations Development Programme (UNDP), the Ministry of Social Integration and Economic Empowerment (MSIE) has launched a national campaign to register all vulnerable families in SRM. NEF project staff were deployed to the field to collect information on printed SRM questionnaires, which were then entered into the Social Register Mauritius system by MSS Officers. The eligibility of the applicants concerning the income status was verified using by PMT, which is built-in, the SRM system. Findings from the SRM registration exercise are expected to guide the identification and prioritization of the genuine and poorest communities across the Island. The purpose of SRM is not only to assist government in identifying the beneficiaries of social programs and deciding the level of assistance for each beneficiary. But also, it is a tool that helps measuring the proportion of vulnerable families which have been sustainably pulled above the Relative Poverty line over time. However, overall, the awareness of the SRM and available schemes is still not optimal among the poor and thus additional outreach and information campaign are advisable and should be ongoing until all of the potential beneficiaries are registered.Moreover, there is need to keep strengthening the results-based monitoring and evaluation system at MSIEE/NEF level to allow technical staff to be capable of carrying out regular process m

indicator.title: Output Indicator
indicator.description:
Effective strategic planning framework in place with allocation of resources linked to long-term and mid-term priorities; PBB Strategic Plans implemented by Ministries, Departments, RRA, other Local Government and all Statutory Bodies
New PFM framework in place; improved capacities and results in performance budgeting , monitoring and control of public expenditure as measured by PEFA assessments; independent budget analysis by CSOs
Learning management system in place; number of staff who have completed web-based courses
Number of social schemes using SRM and PMT; PMT based on latest HBS and Census data

baseline.comment:
Lack of a long-term national plan to support PBB formulation; weak integration of PBB Strategic Plans in budget cycle; PBB Strategic Plans partially prepared by RRA and Statutory bodies; PBB Strategic Plans not prepared by Local Government
Accountability and transparency gaps in existing PFM legislation; lack of e-budgeting and on-line monitoring system; lack of integrated annual reporting; limited budget education in CSOs
Lack of a web-based learning management system; focus on traditional forms of learning; remaining capacity gaps in PFM and public sector management
SRM and PMT applied to crèches and social housing schemes; PMT based on 2005/06 HBS

target.comment: - Formulation of strategy for social inclusion and social entrepreneurship - Contribution to budget proposals in innovation - At least 50% of PBB indicators documented - Budget performance information frameworks improved - Template for annual reports by Ministries and Departments produced - FM Kit reviewed - Capacities in LMS administration developed - Design of 5 on-line courses for the LSM - PMT updated with HBS 2012 data - Capacities of public officers in SRM data collection and SRM data analysis strengthened - SRM software extended to Child Allowance scheme

actual.comment: - Social inclusion and social entrepreneurship strategy submitted to Ministry of Finance and Ministry of Social Integration and ten concrete proposals on social inclusion and social entrepreneurship formulated including rationale, action points, international examples and cost information - Proposal for new innovation schemes formulated, approved by Ministry of Finance and funded in PBB 2014-2016 - 70% of PBB indicators documented - 100% of PBB Strategic Notes and Performance Information for Ministries and Departments reviewed and improved - 100% of PBB Strategic Plans and PBB Performance Frameworks for RRA reviewed and improved - Template and guidelines for the formulation of annual report formulated, integrating financial and non-financial information - Pilot annual report by Ministry of Finance and Economic Development produced for fiscal year 2013 - FM Kit reviewed (proposals submitted to MOFED on amendments to FM Kit Volume 2 – General Financial Procedures) - Capacities of IT and HR officials in LMS administration strengthened - Design and integration of 5 on-line courses for the LMS - Prestigious International Social Security Association (ISSA) Good Practice Award for Africa 2014 won by SRM - PMT updated with HBS 2012 data - Capacity of to 80 officers built on SRM data collection for Child Allowance and other schemes - Capacity of 87 officers on SRM data analysis and PMT application using STATA - SRM software for Child Allowance scheme completed and fully automated

target.comment: - Foresight capacities for an innovative Civil Service strengthened - Draft Marshall Plan against Poverty submitted to Government of Mauritius - Budget framework simplified - PEFA assessment 2015 reviewed - One evaluation programme conducted - Launching of ELS and design of new courses - Traning of NEF officers in SRM management and registration of NEF clients in SRM completed - PMT 2 installed on SRM system

actual.comment: - Foresight capacities strengthened in the Civil Service through Mauritius Foresight Exchange and 4 prototypes for civil service innovation proposed - Draft Marshall Plan against Poverty submitted to Government of Mauritius - Budget framework simplified and 100% of indicators documented for the first time - PEFA assessments reviewed and preliminary lists of areas identified for post PEFA action plan - Evaluation of the Land Drainage programme conducted with results noted by cabinet and capacity of Ministry of Finance (M&E Unit) in programme evaluation strengthened - 5 new ELS courses designed and integrated - ELS management procedures formulated - Registration of NEF clients in SRM completed - 70 NEF officers trained in SRM data collection techniques - Feasibility study on mobile technology to improve outreach to the poor completed - PMT 2 installed and tested on SRM system

indicator.title: Output Indicator
indicator.description: An assessment report on the existing and required policy and regulatory framework as well as institutional capacity to implement the Convention. Mercury awareness raising activities targeting decision makers and population groups at risk such as talks, brochures, pamphlets and flyers. Capacity building and training exercises on how to conduct the mercury inventory targeting at least one representative from the relevant laboratories and institution represented in the Mercury Focus Group. Mercury Inventory (Level 2) conducted and sector description by usage of Mercury developed. A National MIA Report for the ratification and implementation of the Convention

baseline.comment: The “National Inventory of Mercury Releases in Mauritius “ developed in February 2014 under SAICM does not look in details at the institutional capacity needs at national level to implement the Minamata Convention nor does the Inventory provide an analysis of the regulatory and policy framework. As outlined in the “Mauritius National Action Plan for Mercury”, currently there is not much awareness on mercury issues among risk groups, the population and governmental institutions and agencies. No training was conducted locally on how to undertake a Level 2 mercury inventory as per the UNEP toolkit . Limited national capacities capable of performing mercury monitoring in humans and the environment
